longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To make better provision as to the constitution, duties and powers of the Fire Services Department and as to the discipline of members thereof and to make provision for the prevention of fire hazards, for the investigation into matters relating to a fire and for a welfare fund; and to regulate the registration of fire service installation contractors and to provide for the control of the sale, supply, installation, repair, maintenance and inspection of fire service installations or equipment; and to provide for registered fire engineers and a scheme for fire safety risk assessment, and certification on compliance with fire safety requirements, by registered fire engineers for certain premises; and to make provision for purposes connected with the matters aforesaid.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Fire Services Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: calamity (災難) means an occurrence by which life or property is endangered; (Added 1 of 1961 s. 2)
civil service provident fund scheme (公務員公積金計劃) means the Civil Service Provident Fund Scheme referred to in the government regulations; (Added 6 of 2009 s. 3)
Director (處長) means the Director of Fire Services; (Replaced 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any removal from any building of any fire service installation or equipment which was provided in such building in accordance with plans certified by the Director for the purposes of section 16 of the Buildings Ordinance (Cap. 123);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the presence in any building of any fire service installation or equipment which from lack of proper maintenance or for any other reason is not in efficient working order; (Amended 56 of 1969 s. 2)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: inadequate means of egress from any premises in a building to street level outside the building or using such means of egress for a purpose which gives rise to any circumstance described in paragraph (f); (Added 56 of 1969 s. 2. Amended 29 of 1975 s. 2)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any other matter or circumstance which materially increases the likelihood of fire or other calamity or the danger to life or property that would result from the outbreak of fire or the occurrence of any other calamity, or which would materially hamper the Fire Services Department in the discharge of its duties in the event of fire or other calamity; (Added 1 of 1964 s. 3)

def.name: FireServiceInstallationOrEquipment
def.leadIn: fire service installation or equipment (消防裝置或設備) means any installation or equipment manufactured, used or designed to be used for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: extinguishing, attacking, preventing or limiting a fire;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: giving warning of a fire;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: providing access to any premises or place for the purpose of extinguishing, attacking, preventing or limiting a fire; (Added 45 of 1971 s. 3)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: facilitating the evacuation from any premises in case of fire; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 3)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: providing a stand-by power supply to an installation or equipment the purposes of which are mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (d) in the event of the loss of normal power supply; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 3)

section.def: government regulations (政府規例) means the administrative rules known as the Government Regulations and any other administrative rules or instruments regulating the public service; (Replaced 76 of 1999 s. 3)
member (成員) means a person holding any rank in the Fire Services Department set out in the Sixth Schedule; (Replaced 29 of 1975 s. 2)
member of other ranks (員佐級成員) means a member holding a rank set out in Part III of the Sixth Schedule; (Added 29 of 1975 s. 2)

occupier (佔用人) means in the case of domestic buildings a person resident therein and in the case of other buildings means a person carrying on an occupation full-time in such building; (Added 29 of 1975 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in respect of any fire service installation or equipment, includes the occupier or the owner of the premises in or on which the fire service installation or equipment is installed or kept; (Replaced 45 of 1971 s. 3)

section.def: premises (處所) includes any place, but excludes any vessel; (Added 1 of 1964 s. 3. Amended 55 of 1981 s. 2)

def.name: PublicServiceAdministrationOrder
def.leadIn: Public Service (Administration) Order (《公務人員(管理)命令》) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Public Service (Administration) Order 1997 (Executive Order No. 1 of 1997);

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: any other regulation made or any direction given under that Order,

def.continued: as amended from time to time; (Added 76 of 1999 s. 3)

section.def: registered fire engineer (註冊消防工程師) means a person who is registered as a registered fire engineer under the regulations made under this Ordinance; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 4)

registered fire engineer (fire service installation) (註冊消防工程師(消防裝置)) means a person who is registered as a registered fire engineer for the class of fire service installation under the regulations made under this Ordinance; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 4)

registered fire engineer (risk assessment) (註冊消防工程師(風險評估)) means a person who is registered as a registered fire engineer for the class of risk assessment under the regulations made under this Ordinance; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 4)

registered fire engineer (ventilating system) (註冊消防工程師(通風系統)) means a person who is registered as a registered fire engineer for the class of ventilating system under the regulations made under this Ordinance; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 4)

def.name: RetirementBenefits
def.leadIn: retirement benefits (退休福利), in relation to a person, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the pension, gratuity or other allowance of that person as provided for under the Pensions Ordinance (Cap. 89);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the pension benefits of that person as provided for under the Pension Benefits Ordinance (Cap. 99); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the part of that person’s beneficial interests in the civil service provident fund scheme that is attributable to sums derived from the voluntary contributions made by the Government, as employer, in respect of that person under section 11(4) of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485), together with the income, profits or losses arising from any investment of those sums and of such income or profits; (Added 6 of 2009 s. 3)

section.def: senior officer (高級人員) means a member holding a rank set out in Part I of the Sixth Schedule; (Replaced 29 of 1975 s. 2)
subordinate officer (部屬人員) means a member holding a rank set out in Part II of the Sixth Schedule; (Replaced 29 of 1975 s. 2)
tenant (租客) includes sub-tenant; (Added 54 of 1986 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any ship (not being a ship of war or a ship having the status of a ship of war), junk, boat, dynamically supported craft, seaplane or any other description of vessel used in navigation; and (Amended 41 of 1992 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other description of vessel not used in navigation or not constructed or adapted for use in navigation. (Added 55 of 1981 s. 2)

subsection.content: The Fire Services Department shall consist of such senior officers, subordinate officers and members of other ranks as the Chief Executive may direct. (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

A person holding a post in the Fire Services Department specified in the Seventh Schedule shall be deemed to be a member of the Department for the purposes of sections 6(2), 22, 23, 27(1) and 28. (Amended 4 of 1986 s. 2)

section.name: s4
section.heading: Terms of service of members of the Fire Services Department
section.text: The Pensions Ordinance (Cap. 89), the Pension Benefits Ordinance (Cap. 99), the Public Service Commission Ordinance (Cap. 93), Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations for the time being in force, save in so far as is otherwise provided therein or in this Ordinance or in any regulations made under this Ordinance, shall apply to all members.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Administration of Fire Services Department by Director
section.text: The Director, subject to the orders and control of the Chief Executive, shall be charged with the supreme direction and administration of the Fire Services Department.

subsection.content: Save where the contrary intention appears from the context of any enactment and subject to any special instructions of the Director, a Deputy Director of Fire Services may exercise or discharge any of the powers or duties which the Director by any enactment is entitled to exercise or required to discharge.

Save where the contrary intention appears from the context of any enactment and subject to any special instructions of the Chief Executive, the Director may authorize any member, not being below the rank of subordinate officer, by name, office or appointment, to exercise or discharge any of the powers or duties which the Director by any enactment is entitled to exercise or required to discharge. (Amended 29 of 1975 s. 4; 76 of 1999 s. 3)
For the avoidance of doubt, nothing in this section shall be deemed to derogate from any power of delegation conferred upon the Director by the provisions of any other enactment.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Duties of Fire Services Department
section.leadIn: The duties of the Fire Services Department shall be to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: extinguish fires; (Replaced 55 of 1981 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: protect life and property in case of fire or other calamity; (Replaced 55 of 1981 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: give advice on fire protection measures and fire hazards as occasion requires; (Replaced 55 of 1981 s. 3)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: assist any person who appears to need prompt or immediate medical attention by—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: securing his safety;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: resuscitating or sustaining his life;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: reducing his suffering or distress;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any person referred to in paragraph (d) to a hospital or other place where medical attention is available to him; and

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: carry out such other duties as may be imposed on it by law or by any direction of the Chief Executive; and (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: do any thing which is necessary or desirable to carry out effectively any duty which is specified in this section or imposed under paragraph (f).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this section, the Director or any person authorized by him in writing on producing, if so required, the writing showing his authority, shall have a right to enter any premises at all reasonable hours for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ascertaining whether there is, or has been, on or in connexion with the premises, any contravention of any of the provisions of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: obtaining information required for fire-fighting purposes with respect to the character of the premises, the available water supplies and the means of access thereto, and other material circumstances;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ascertaining whether or not there exists any fire hazard;

content.leadIn: the performance by the Director or by the Fire Services Department of his or its powers or duties under any enactment:
content.proviso: Provided that the Director, or any person authorized by him in writing, shall not exercise the right of entry conferred by this subsection in respect of such premises as are not a place of public entertainment or public assembly, factory, workshop or workplace nor premises otherwise used for business purposes, unless 24 hours’ notice in writing of the intended entry has been given to the occupier.

subsection.leadIn: If it is shown to the satisfaction of a magistrate on sworn information in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that admission to any premises has been refused, or that refusal is apprehended, or that the premises are unoccupied or the occupier is temporarily absent, or that the case is one of urgency, or that an application for admission would defeat the object of the entry; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there is reasonable ground for entry into the premises for any purpose specified in subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the notice of the intention to apply for the warrant has been given to the occupier of the premises, or that the premises are unoccupied, or that the occupier is temporarily absent, or that the case is one of urgency, or that the giving of such notice would defeat the object of the entry,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may by warrant in the form of Form 1 in the Fifth Schedule authorize the Director, or any person authorized by the Director in writing in that behalf, to enter the premises, if need be by force. (Amended 29 of 1975 s. 6; 47 of 1997 s. 10)

subsection.content: The Director or any person entering any premises by virtue of this section, or of a warrant issued hereunder, may take with him such persons as may be necessary, and on leaving any unoccupied premises which he has entered by virtue of such a warrant shall leave them as effectually secured against trespassers as he found them to be at the time of entry.
Every warrant granted under this section shall continue in force until the purpose for which the entry is necessary has been satisfied.

If any person who, in compliance with this section or a warrant issued hereunder, enters a factory, workshop, workplace or premises used for business purposes discloses to any person any information obtained by him in the factory, workshop or workplace or premises used for business purposes with regard to any manufacturing process or trade secret, he shall, unless such disclosure was made in the performance of his duty, be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 4. (Amended 25 of 1982 s. 2; 7 of 2003 s. 13)

Within a reasonable period after a fire in or on any premises has been extinguished, the Director or any member authorized by the Director in writing on producing, if so required, the document showing the member’s authority, may enter the premises for the purpose of investigation into the cause of or other matters relating to the fire.

subsection.leadIn: Having entered the premises, the Director or member—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may stay in or on the premises for so long as it is reasonably necessary for the purpose referred to in subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may remove and take possession of any article or thing found in or on the premises that the Director or member has reasonable cause to believe is necessary for the purpose referred to in subsection (1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may deal with the article or thing referred to in paragraph (b) in such a way as appears to the Director or member to be reasonably necessary for examination or analysis;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: may retain the article or thing referred to in paragraph (b) for so long as it is reasonably necessary for examination or analysis;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: may take such photographs and make such video recordings as the Director or member has reasonable cause to believe is necessary for the purpose referred to in subsection (1);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: may require any person whom the Director or member has reasonable cause to believe is able to give any information relevant to the purpose referred to in subsection (1)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to attend at a time and place specified by the Director or member;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to answer (in the absence of persons other than any person whom the Director or member may allow to be present and a person nominated to be present by the person on whom the requirement is imposed) such questions as the Director or member thinks fit to ask; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to sign a declaration of the truth of the person’s answer;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: may require the production of, and inspect and take copies of documents that the Director or member has reasonable cause to believe is necessary for the purpose referred to in subsection (1);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: may require any person to afford the Director or member such facilities and assistance with respect to any article or thing within that person’s control or in relation to which that person has responsibilities as the Director or member considers reasonably necessary to exercise any of the powers conferred by this subsection.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be taken to compel a person to disclose any information or produce any document that the person would on grounds of legal professional privilege be entitled to refuse to disclose or produce.

On leaving any unoccupied premises that the Director or member entered under this section, the Director or member shall leave them as effectually secured against trespassers as the Director or member found them to be at the time of entry.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director or member who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: obtains any information from the answer given or document obtained under subsection (2)(f) or (g), as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in compliance with this section, enters a factory, workshop, workplace or premises used for business purposes,

subsection.continued: discloses to any person any information obtained by the Director or member under subsection (2)(f) or (g) or in the factory, workshop, workplace or premises with regard to any manufacturing process or trade secret, the Director or member shall, unless the disclosure is made in the performance of the Director’s or member’s duty, be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 4.

subsection.content: This section shall not affect the power of the Commissioner of Police under the Fire Investigation Ordinance (Cap. 12).

section.name: s8B
section.heading: Answers that may implicate criminal liability
section.content: If an answer to a question asked under section 8A(2)(f)(ii) tends to incriminate the person who gave the answer, neither the question nor the answer shall be admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings other than proceedings for an offence under section 36 of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200) in respect of the answer given.

section.name: s8C
section.heading: Disposal of article or thing removed and possessed by Director or member for purpose of fire investigation

subsection.leadIn: If any article or thing is removed from any premises and possessed by the Director or a member under section 8A(2)(b), a notice in both English and Chinese shall be caused to be affixed by the Director or member at a conspicuous part of the premises—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: setting out details of the article or thing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: calling for submission, within 1 month after the day on which the notice was affixed, of any claim for the return of the article or thing after it has been examined or analysed under section 8A(2)(c).

subsection.content: If a claim is made under subsection (1) for the return of the article or thing, the Director or member may refuse to return it unless satisfied that the claimant is the owner or otherwise entitled to possession of the article or thing.

If the article or thing is not claimed within the period under subsection (1), or if the Director or member refuses to return it under subsection (2), the article or thing may be disposed of in such a way as the Director or member thinks fit.

section.name: s8D
section.heading: Disposal of property connected with offences
section.content: Section 102 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) shall apply with respect to any property came into the possession of the Director or a member in connection with an offence under this Ordinance as it applies with respect to the property in the possession of a court, magistrate, the police or the Customs and Excise Service.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Power of Director in respect of abatement and prevention of fire hazards
section.leadIn: For the purpose of abating a fire hazard or preventing it from recurring, the Director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if satisfied of the existence in or on any premises of any fire hazard, may serve a prescribed notice on a person requiring the person to do such things as may be specified by the Director to abate the fire hazard within the period specified in the notice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, under the prescribed circumstances, cause to be carried out any works in respect of any premises and recover the expenses incurred from any person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may, under the prescribed circumstances, remove and take possession of any article or thing and dispose of it in the prescribed manner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: may, under the prescribed circumstances, cause to be registered in the Land Registry any information concerning any premises in relation to which a person is charged with, convicted of, acquitted of or successfully appeals against a conviction of an offence under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: may cause to be publicised by the prescribed means the fact of a conviction of an offence under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: may apply to a court or magistrate for an order—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
iii
subparagraph.content: that requires a person to abate a fire hazard or prevent it from recurring; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: that requires a person to remove any article or thing that obstructs or may obstruct, or locks or may lock the means of escape in any premises. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2021)

section.name: s10
section.heading: Powers of Fire Services Department on occasion of fire
section.leadIn: The Director or other member in charge of the Fire Services Department or any contingent thereof on the occasion of a fire or other calamity may— (Amended 1 of 1961 s. 4; 42 of 1961 s. 2; 29 of 1975 s. 9)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take such measures as may appear to him to be necessary or expedient for the protection of life and property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remove or order any member under his command to remove any person interfering by his presence or actions with the operations of the Fire Services Department; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by himself or members under his command enter, break into or through and take possession of or demolish or cause to be taken possession of or demolished any premises, vessel or thing for the purpose of putting an end to the fire or minimizing the effect of the calamity; (Amended 1 of 1961 s. 4; 41 of 1992 s. 3)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: close any street near the site of the fire or calamity; (Amended 1 of 1961 s. 4)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: use any convenient supply of water.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Power to fix fire hydrant and emergency water supply location plates

subsection.content: Upon giving 7 days’ notice in writing to the owner of any property situate in the vicinity of a fire hydrant or emergency water supply, the Director may cause a plate indicating the location of such fire hydrant or water supply to be fixed to such part of the property as may, in the opinion of the Director, be best suited to indicate such location. (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

Any person who refuses to allow the fixing of any such plate as is referred to in subsection (1) or obstructs any person in the course of the fixing thereof or removes or defaces any such plate after it has been so fixed shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended 7 of 2003 s. 13)

section.name: s12
section.heading: Offences against discipline generally
section.content: Any member who commits any of the offences against discipline specified in the First Schedule shall be liable to be dismissed or otherwise dealt with as provided in this Ordinance and in regulations made thereunder.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Offences against discipline by senior officers
section.leadIn: Whenever it is alleged that any senior officer has been guilty of an offence against discipline or whenever an investigation is being undertaken into any conduct which may amount to the commission of an offence against discipline by a senior officer— (Amended 50 of 1978 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the provisions of Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations which relate to interdiction shall apply; (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the matter shall be investigated and the senior officer dealt with in the appropriate manner provided by the said regulations and orders for allegations of misconduct made against a public officer.

section.name: s13A
section.heading: Liability of subordinate officers and members of other ranks to summary dismissal upon abscondment

subsection.leadIn: Where a subordinate officer or member of other ranks is absent from duty without leave for a period exceeding 14 days and the Director is satisfied that— (Amended 7 of 2003 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subordinate officer or member of other ranks cannot be traced; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on being required by notice in writing (sent to an address or addresses through which it may be reasonably expected to reach him) to give, within the period specified in the notice, an excuse for his absence, the subordinate officer or member of other ranks has failed to give any excuse or to give an excuse that is acceptable,

subsection.continued: the Director may dispense with an investigation and summarily dismiss the subordinate officer or member of other ranks.

subsection.content: Where a subordinate officer or member of other ranks is summarily dismissed by the Director pursuant to subsection (1), he may appeal against such dismissal in accordance with the Fourth Schedule.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Offences against discipline by subordinate officer and member of other ranks

subsection.leadIn: The Director may interdict a subordinate officer or member of other ranks from the exercise of the powers and functions of his office whenever—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is charged with an offence against discipline; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an investigation is being undertaken into any conduct which may amount to the commission of an offence against discipline and the Director considers that it is contrary to the public interest for the subordinate officer or member of other ranks to continue to exercise the powers and functions of his office.

subsection.content: A subordinate officer or member of other ranks who is interdicted under subsection (1)(b) shall be entitled until such time as he is charged with a disciplinary offence to the full amount of the emoluments of his office which he would have received if he had not been interdicted.

subsection.leadIn: A subordinate officer or member of other ranks who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is interdicted under subsection (1)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having been interdicted under subsection (1)(b), is charged with a disciplinary offence,

subsection.continued: shall receive such proportion of the emoluments of his office, not being less than one-half, as the Director thinks fit.

subsection.content: Whenever it is alleged that a subordinate officer or member of other ranks has committed a disciplinary offence, investigation shall be made into the allegation in the manner provided for by Part I of the Second Schedule and punishment may be awarded in accordance with the provisions of the Third Schedule.
Notwithstanding section 6(2), the Director shall not authorize any other member to exercise the power of dismissal conferred on him by the Third Schedule.

If proceedings against a subordinate officer or member of other ranks do not result in any punishment he shall be entitled to the full amount of the emoluments which he would have received if he had not been interdicted.

If a punishment other than dismissal is awarded, any subordinate officer or member of other ranks may be paid such proportion of the emoluments withheld as a result of his interdiction as the Chief Executive thinks fit where the punishment is imposed by the Chief Executive or as the Director thinks fit in every other case. (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s14A
section.heading: Criminal offences by subordinate officers and members of other ranks

subsection.content: If criminal proceedings have been, or are likely to be, instituted against a subordinate officer or member of other ranks, or an investigation is being undertaken into any conduct which may amount to the commission of a criminal offence by such officer or member, he may be interdicted and paid emoluments in accordance with section 14 which shall (except subsection (4)) apply, with all necessary modifications, to an interdiction under this subsection.

If in criminal proceedings before any court a subordinate officer or member of other ranks is found guilty of or pleads guilty to a criminal offence and any appeal in or other application for review of those proceedings is not allowed or is withdrawn, the officer or member may be punished in accordance with Part II of the Second Schedule. (Amended L.N. 262 of 1978)

Notwithstanding subsection (1), a subordinate officer or member of other ranks who is found guilty of or pleads guilty to a criminal offence which in the opinion of the Director is serious enough to warrant his dismissal shall not, as from the time when he is found or pleads guilty as aforesaid or when he is interdicted (whichever is the later), be paid any emoluments of his office pending consideration of the case in accordance with Part II of the Second Schedule.

def.name: CriminalProceedings,CriminalOffence
def.leadIn: In this section, criminal proceedings (刑事法律程序) and criminal offence (刑事罪行) include respectively—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: criminal proceedings in, and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a criminal offence against the law of,

subsection.leadIn: The provisions in the Fourth Schedule shall have effect for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: making provision as to the bringing and disposal of such appeals and the procedure therefor.

subsection.content: Any restriction in law on the power of the Chief Executive to delegate the hearing of an appeal shall not apply to an appeal referred to in subsection (1). (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

Where a subordinate officer or member of other ranks has been found guilty of a disciplinary offence and has been punished by the Director or another member, the Director may, of his own motion, within 14 days of the finding or the punishment (if it was awarded on a later day), and in accordance with the provisions of the Fourth Schedule, review the finding or punishment or both, and within 14 days of the punishment he may review the punishment awarded following a plea of guilty to a disciplinary offence.

section.name: s14C
section.heading: Payment for loss or damage to property

subsection.leadIn: Where the Chief Executive or the Director has found a subordinate officer or member of other ranks guilty of an offence against discipline, the Chief Executive or the Director may, in addition to any punishment that the Chief Executive or the Director is empowered to award in accordance with the provisions of the Third Schedule, order such subordinate officer or member of other ranks to pay to the Government in full or in part— (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any article of clothing, equipment or property whatsoever entrusted or supplied to him in his capacity as a subordinate officer or member of other ranks which has been lost or damaged by him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any Government property lost or damaged by him; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the amount of any compensation paid, ex gratia or otherwise, by the Government to any person in respect of the loss or damage of that person’s property caused by the subordinate officer or member of other ranks,

subsection.continued: but only in each case if the loss or damage has resulted from the neglect or fault of such subordinate officer or member of other ranks and the amount ordered to be paid does not exceed his salary for one month.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may require a subordinate officer or member of other ranks to pay to the Government in full or in part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any article of clothing, equipment or property whatsoever entrusted or supplied to him in his capacity as a subordinate officer or member of other ranks which has been lost or damaged by him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the cost of repairing or replacing any Government property lost or damaged by him; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the amount of any compensation paid, ex gratia or otherwise, by the Government to any person in respect of the loss or damage of that person’s property caused by the subordinate officer or member of other ranks,

subsection.continued: but only in each case if the loss or damage has resulted from the neglect or fault of such subordinate officer or member of other ranks and the amount ordered to be paid does not exceed his salary for one month.

subsection.content: For the purpose of enabling due inquiry to be made as to whether a subordinate officer or member of other ranks should be required to pay any amount under subsection (2), affording him due opportunity to make representations and enabling any requirement under that subsection to be appealed against and reviewed, Part III shall apply mutatis mutandis to and in respect of such a requirement as it applies to and in respect of a finding of guilty of an offence against discipline in accordance with the provisions of the Third Schedule and an award of punishment.

subsection.leadIn: The following penal deductions may be made from the emoluments due to a member—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all emoluments for every day of absence either on desertion or without leave;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sum required to pay any fine or other sum ordered to be paid on conviction for a criminal offence or for an offence against discipline.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no member shall be treated as absent unless the absence has lasted 6 hours or upwards except where the absence prevented the prompt dispatch of any contingent, appliance, ambulance, fire boat, or vehicle of the Fire Services Department in answer to any call; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of days shall be reckoned as from the time when the absence commences.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Removal of doubt
section.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt it is hereby declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if criminal proceedings have been, or are likely to be, instituted against a senior officer, or an investigation is being undertaken into any conduct which may amount to the commission of a criminal offence by a senior officer, he may be interdicted from duty and paid emoluments in accordance with Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations; (Replaced 50 of 1978 s. 5)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a senior officer who in criminal proceeding before any court is found guilty of or pleads guilty to any offence may be punished in accordance with Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations; (Replaced 29 of 1975 s. 12)

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: nothing in this Part shall be construed to preclude the termination of the employment in accordance with Public Service (Administration) Order of a member on the ground that, having regard to the conditions of the public service, the usefulness of the member thereto and all the other circumstances of the case, such termination is desirable in the public interest. (Added 33 of 1965 s. 4)

section.name: s18
section.heading: Definitions: Part IV

def.name: Amenities
def.leadIn: amenities (設施活動) means any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: facilities that are not chargeable to the general revenue, including holiday premises and recreational facilities (whether provided free or for a charge);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: social, educational and recreational activities and performances (whether provided free or for a charge and whether provided for participation or as spectator events);

def.name: Beneficiaries
def.leadIn: beneficiaries (受益人) means the following persons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Fire Services employees;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: former Fire Services employees;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: dependants of deceased Fire Services employees;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: dependants of deceased former Fire Services employees;

section.def: Department means the Fire Services Department;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a Fire Services employee or a former Fire Services employee—a person who, in the opinion of the Director, is wholly or partially dependent on the employee or former employee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a deceased Fire Services employee or a deceased former Fire Services employee—a person who, in the opinion of the Director, was, at the time of the death of the employee or former employee, wholly or partially dependent on the employee or former employee;

section.def: dispose of (處置) means dispose of by sale, lease, hiring, mortgage or any other lawful means;
Fire Services employee (消防處僱員) means any person employed in the Department;
Fire Services Staff Purchase Scheme (消防處職員購物計劃) means the scheme (if any) established under section 19E;

def.name: FormerFireServicesEmployee
def.leadIn: former Fire Services employee (前消防處僱員) means a person who was formerly a Fire Services employee and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who has retired from the Department with retirement benefits; or (Amended 6 of 2009 s. 21)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whose contract of service as a member of the Department has expired on or after the person reached 55 years of age without the contract being renewed;

section.def: this Part (本部) includes regulations made under section 25(b).

section.name: s19
section.heading: Director to be corporation sole for purposes of this Part

subsection.content: The Director is constituted as a corporation sole for the purposes of this Part with the corporate name of “Director of Fire Services Incorporated”.

subsection.leadIn: The corporation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has perpetual succession; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of this Part, may acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may take legal proceedings and be proceeded against in its corporate name; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is required to have a corporate seal; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: for the purposes of this Part, has the capacity to do and be subjected to all other things that bodies corporate may, by law, do and be subjected to.

subsection.content: A document requiring authentication by the corporation is sufficiently authenticated if it is signed by the Director or by any Fire Services employee authorized to do so by the Director.
The affixing of the corporate seal to a document executed by the corporation is not valid unless authenticated by the Director or a Fire Services employee designated for the purpose by the Director.

The corporation is not a trustee for the beneficiaries, but, subject to subsection (6), nothing in this Part limits a right conferred by law to bring legal proceedings against the corporation for a contravention of this Part or a failure to perform a duty imposed by this Part.

Neither the Director nor any delegate of the corporation is personally liable in any legal proceedings arising out of an act done or omitted to be done in relation to the Fund if the act was done or omitted to be done in good faith for the purpose of giving effect to this Part.

section.name: s19A
section.heading: Continuance of Fire Services Department Welfare Fund

subsection.content: The fund called the “Fire Services Department Welfare Fund” in English and “消防處福利基金” in Chinese is continued by this section.
The Fund and the property derived from the application of the Fund are vested in the corporation.

section.name: s19B
section.heading: What the Fund consists of
section.leadIn: The Fund consists of the following—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any donations made to the Fund;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if a Fire Services Staff Purchase Scheme is established under section 19E, proceeds derived from transactions under the Scheme;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: proceeds from the sale of souvenirs and the disposal of other property held for the purposes of the Fund;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: all fees collected from social, educational and recreational activities organized by or on behalf of the Director for the purposes of the Fund;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: money derived from the investment of the Fund;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: money accruing as interest on loans made from the Fund;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: gifts of money required under the notice from time to time given by the Chief Executive for the purposes of section 3 of the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance (Cap. 201) to be disposed of by being paid into the Fund; (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 214; 26 of 2012 s. 44)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: any money voted to the Fund by the Legislative Council;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: money held in the Fund immediately before the commencement* of Schedule 1 to the Disciplined Services Welfare Funds Legislation (Amendment) Ordinance 1999 (58 of 1999) and money which was, immediately before that commencement, recoverable for the Fund and which is subsequently paid to, or recovered for, the Fund after that commencement;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: money paid or payable to the credit of the Fund from any other lawful source.

subsection.content: Subject to this Part, the principal function of the corporation is to administer the Fund, and the property derived from the application of the Fund, for the benefit of beneficiaries and others as provided by this Part.
The corporation has such ancillary functions as are necessary to enable it to perform its principal function.

subsection.leadIn: The corporation is required—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to act honestly in all matters relating to its principal function; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to exercise in relation to all matters relating to the administration of the Fund the same degree of care, skill and diligence as an ordinary prudent person would exercise in dealing with property of another person for whom the person felt morally bound to provide; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to ensure that its functions relating to the Fund are performed or exercised in the best interests of beneficiaries.

section.name: s19D
section.heading: What the Fund may be used for

subsection.leadIn: The Fund may be used for any of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing and maintaining amenities for the use and enjoyment of the beneficiaries;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making payments to the corporation’s employees in respect of their employment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: making payments for the services of the corporation’s agents;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: compensating Fire Services employees for extra services provided by them;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: making loans to beneficiaries;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: granting financial assistance to dependants of deceased Fire Services employees and deceased former Fire Services employees in order to meet the funeral expenses of those deceased employees and deceased former employees;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: making grants, allowances and gifts to beneficiaries for purposes other than the purpose mentioned in paragraph (f);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: making or acquiring souvenirs for sale to beneficiaries and others;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: if a Fire Services Staff Purchase Scheme is established under section 19E, undertaking transactions for the purpose of giving effect to the Scheme;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: making donations to charitable or community organizations;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: paying interest that is payable on loans made to the corporation or the Fund.

subsection.leadIn: The corporation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may dispose of property derived from the application of the Fund that is, in its opinion, no longer required for the purposes of the Fund; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may pay from the Fund the expenses incurred in disposing of the property.

subsection.content: Loans to beneficiaries may, at the discretion of the corporation, be granted free of interest or subject to the payment of interest.

Whenever the Director considers it appropriate to do so, the Director may permit persons who are not beneficiaries to enjoy the use of amenities derived from the application of the Fund. Permission may be granted subject to such conditions as the Director considers appropriate.

section.name: s19E
section.heading: Corporation may establish Fire Services Staff Purchase Scheme

subsection.leadIn: The corporation may establish and maintain a scheme, to be known as the Fire Services Staff Purchase Scheme, under which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Fund may be used to acquire goods or services for resupply to beneficiaries, or to finance arrangements for the supply of goods or services to beneficiaries; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: payment by beneficiaries for the goods or services may be made either in a single cash sum or by instalments.

subsection.content: If a Fire Services Staff Purchase Scheme is established, the corporation must ensure that the proceeds derived from transactions under the Scheme are credited to the Fund.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section, supply (供應) and resupply (重新供應) mean supply and resupply for sale.

section.name: s19F
section.heading: Corporation may make donations
section.content: The corporation may, whenever appropriate, donate money from the Fund to charitable or community organizations on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: The corporation may, for the purposes of this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: employ persons under contracts of employment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: use the services of any staff or facilities of the Department.

subsection.content: The corporation may fix the remuneration and other conditions of employment of its staff.

section.name: s19H
section.heading: Corporation may engage agents
section.content: The corporation may engage and pay agents to transact any business or do any act (including receiving or paying money) that the corporation is authorized or required to do for the purposes of this Part.

subsection.content: The corporation may delegate to a Fire Services employee any of its functions, other than this power of delegation.

subsection.leadIn: A delegation under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be general or limited; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be revoked, wholly or partly, by the corporation.

subsection.content: A delegated function is to be performed or exercised only in accordance with any conditions to which the delegation is subject.
A delegate may, in the performance or exercise of a function delegated under this section, exercise any other function that is incidental to the delegated function.
A delegated function that is duly performed or exercised by a delegate is taken to have been performed or exercised by the corporation.

subsection.leadIn: If a function is delegated to the holder of a particular office in the Department—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the delegation does not cease to have effect merely because the person who was the holder of the office when the function was delegated ceases to be the holder of that office; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the function may be exercised, or, in the case of a duty, must be performed, by the person for the time being occupying or acting in the office.

subsection.content: A function that has been delegated may be performed or exercised by the corporation despite the delegation.

section.name: s19J
section.heading: Corporation may enter into contracts and other transactions

subsection.content: The corporation may enter into contracts and other transactions for the purposes of the Fund.
A person who pays money under a contract or other transaction purporting to be entered into under this section has no obligation to see that the money is paid into the Fund.

A person who enters into a contract or other transaction with a Fire Services employee who purports to be a delegate of the corporation has no obligation to be satisfied that the corporation has delegated to the employee the power to enter into the contract or other transaction.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may make orders called “Fire Services Department General Orders” not inconsistent with the provisions of— (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Ordinance and any regulations made thereunder;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Stores Regulations of the Government;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Public Service (Administration) Order and government regulations, as modified by this Ordinance and by regulations made thereunder. (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Such orders may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the control, direction and information of the Fire Services Department; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: discipline;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: training;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: classifications and promotions;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: inspections, drills, exercises and parades;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: welfare;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: departmental finance;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: buildings, grounds, stores, furniture and equipment;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: services to be performed by members;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the manner and form of reports, correspondence and other records;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the performance of any act which may be necessary for the proper carrying out of the provisions of this Ordinance or any regulations made thereunder or of any other enactment or for the discharge of any duty imposed by law on the Fire Services Department; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: such other matters as may be necessary or expedient for preventing abuse or neglect of duty, for rendering the Fire Services Department efficient in the discharge of its duties and for carrying out the objects of this Ordinance. (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

subsection.content: Save where subsection (2) applies, a damage done by the Fire Services Department in the discharge of its duty on the occasion of a fire or an incident that may pose an immediate danger of fire is taken to be a damage by fire within the meaning of a policy of insurance against fire.

For the purpose of a policy of insurance against fire that was executed immediately before the commencement* of section 10 of the Fire Services (Amendment) Ordinance 2003 (7 of 2003), a damage done by the Fire Services Department in the discharge of its duty on the occasion of a fire is taken to be a damage by fire within the meaning of the policy of insurance against fire.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Protection of members of Fire Services Department

subsection.content: No member acting bona fide under powers conferred by this Ordinance shall be liable to any action for damages for any act done or omitted to be done by him in connexion with his duties on the occasion of a fire or other calamity. (Amended 1 of 1961 s. 7; 42 of 1961 s. 2)

Where a member has done or omitted to do any thing in connexion with his duties which he is empowered to do or omit to do on the occasion of a fire or other calamity, and it is subsequently discovered that a fire or other calamity had not in fact occurred, such act or omission shall be deemed to have been done or omitted pursuant to this Ordinance if it was done or omitted in good faith and would have been lawfully done or omitted if a fire or other calamity had in fact occurred. (Added 29 of 1975 s. 15)

On the application of any person, the Director may, if he thinks fit, detail any member to perform special services in, upon or about any premises, vessel, vehicle or aircraft specified by the applicant and for the purpose furnish such equipment as he may deem necessary. (Amended 33 of 1956 s. 6; 42 of 1961 s. 2; 29 of 1975 s. 16; 58 of 1999 s. 2)

The applicant shall pay to the Director for the services of any member so detailed and for the use of equipment so furnished such fees as the Director may think fit. (Amended 33 of 1956 s. 6; 42 of 1961 s. 2)

All fees so received by the Director shall be paid by him into the Treasury forthwith to the credit of the Fire Services Department Welfare Fund and be accounted for monthly and shall be recoverable by action in like manner as other Government debts. (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2; 76 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation provide for— (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3; 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: discipline and punishment of subordinate officers and members of other ranks; (Amended 29 of 1975 s. 17)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the control, administration and investment of the Fire Services Department Welfare Fund; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2; 58 of 1999 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: description of uniforms and equipment to be provided;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such other matters as may be necessary or expedient for rendering the Fire Services Department efficient in the discharge of its duties; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the making and issue of reports and certificates regarding—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: fires or other calamities attended by the Fire Services Department; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: premises, vessels or other property damaged by fire;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: matters relating to fire risks or fire precautions in or connected with any premises, vessel or other property,

paragraph.continued: and fees to be charged in relation thereto; (Added 1 of 1961 s. 8)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the registration and de-registration of fire service installation contractors and fees to be charged in relation thereto; (Added 45 of 1971 s. 4. Amended 34 of 1986 s. 2)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the appointment, powers and procedure of a disciplinary board in relation to fire service installation contractors; (Added 45 of 1971 s. 4)

paragraph.name: g
g
paragraph.content: fees to be charged in relation to the registration and de-registration of registered fire engineers; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the establishment, powers and procedure of a registration committee in relation to the registration of registered fire engineers; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the establishment of an interview board panel, and the appointment, powers and procedure of interview boards, in relation to the registration of registered fire engineers; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the duties of registered fire engineers in relation to fire safety risk assessment, and certification on compliance with fire safety requirements, for premises prescribed by regulations made under this section; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the acts or omissions that constitute a disciplinary offence on the part of a registered fire engineer; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the establishment of a disciplinary board panel, and the appointment, powers and procedure of disciplinary boards, in relation to registered fire engineers; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: hb
paragraph.leadIn: the grounds on which appeals may be lodged in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the registration of registered fire engineers; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: registered fire engineers; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the establishment of an appeal board panel, and the appointment, powers and procedure of appeal boards, in relation to appeals mentioned in paragraph (gh); (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the issue of codes of practice concerning fire safety of any premises, and giving guidance in relation to the professional conduct, and the administration, of registered fire engineers; (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the control of the sale, supply, installation, repair, maintenance and inspection of fire service installations or equipment; (Added 45 of 1971 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ha
paragraph.content: fees or charges payable in respect of carrying into effect the provisions of the Ordinance (other than provisions relating to the discharge of any duty imposed by law on the Fire Services Department), whether similar or not to any matter mentioned in this section; (Added 34 of 1986 s. 2. Amended L.N. 63 of 1992)

paragraph.name: hb
paragraph.leadIn: the making of an order by a court or magistrate—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that requires a person to abate a fire hazard or prevent it from recurring;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that closes any premises in relation to which a person has been convicted of an offence under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that rescinds or suspends an order under subparagraph (ii);

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: that prohibits any premises to be used for a particular purpose;

subparagraph.name: v
vi
subparagraph.content: that terminates the tenancy of any premises; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hc
paragraph.content: the procedure and other matters relating to an order under paragraph (hb); (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hd
paragraph.content: the prevention of obstruction to and locking of the means of escape in any premises; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: he
paragraph.content: the regulation of the conveyance on land of a container that contains a part of a motor vehicle that has fuel in its fuel tank or is otherwise stained with fuel; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hf
paragraph.content: the regulation of the stowage of a part of a motor vehicle that has fuel in its fuel tank or is otherwise stained with fuel, in a container that is or is to be conveyed on land; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hg
paragraph.content: the powers of any prescribed public officer to stop, board and search a vehicle or enter and search a container and seize, remove and detain articles or things carried in, on or by the vehicle or contained in the container that is related to an offence under this Ordinance; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hh
paragraph.content: the prohibition of possession or control of a prescribed substance in or on any prescribed premises for the purpose of a business of supplying the substance for transferring to the fuel tank of a motor vehicle; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hi
paragraph.content: the power of the Director to obtain, or to authorize a member in writing to obtain, personal particulars from any person under the prescribed circumstances; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hj
paragraph.content: the liability of the owner, tenant, occupier or person in charge of any premises who knowingly permits or suffers an offence under this Ordinance to be committed in or on the premises; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hk
paragraph.content: the liability of a person who lets, or agrees to let, whether as principal or agent of another person, any premises with the knowledge that an offence under this Ordinance is to be committed in or on the premises; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: hl
paragraph.content: the prescribing of anything required to be prescribed under this Ordinance; (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: generally, for the carrying into effect of the provisions of the Ordinance in relation to any matter, whether similar or not to those in this section mentioned, as to which it may be convenient to make regulations.

subsection.content: A regulation made under this section may provide that the Director may not authorize members of certain ranks to exercise a power or discharge a duty that the Director by any enactment is entitled to exercise or required to discharge. (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

subsection.leadIn: A regulation made under this section may provide that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any contravention of the provisions of the regulation shall be an offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who contravenes the regulation shall be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $300,000 and to imprisonment for a period not exceeding 1 year, and in the case of a continuing offence, to a daily penalty not exceeding $30,000. (Added 7 of 2003 s. 11)

subsection.content: A regulation made under subsection (1)(ga), (gc), (gd), (ge), (gf), (gg), (gh), (gi) or (gj) is subject to the approval of the Legislative Council. (Added 1 of 2017 s. 5)

section.name: s26
section.heading: Amendment of Schedules
section.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation amend— (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Sixth and Seventh Schedules to show respectively the ranks in the Fire Services Department and the posts specified for the purposes of section 3(2) in such manner as he thinks fit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other Schedule to make therein any provision which he could make by regulation under section 25.

subsection.content: Any person who, without reasonable excuse, resists, obstructs or delays any member acting in the exercise of the member’s power, or in the discharge of any duty conferred by this Ordinance, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Replaced 7 of 2003 s. 12)

subsection.leadIn: Any member who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: deserts;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the occasion of a fire or other calamity wilfully disobeys a lawful command of a member whom it is his duty to obey, (Amended 29 of 1975 s. 19)

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended 25 of 1982 s. 5)

subsection.content: Any person who, not being a member, wears, without permission of the Director, the uniform of the Fire Services Department, or any dress having the appearance or bearing any of the distinctive marks of that uniform, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2; 29 of 1975 s. 19)

section.name: s28
section.heading: False alarms of fire
section.content: Any person who gives or causes to be given an alarm of fire or other calamity which he knows to be false to the Fire Services Department or to any member shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

schedule.name: sch1
schedule.heading: Offences against Discipline
schedule.leadIn: Any member commits an offence against discipline who—

subsection.content: is guilty of cowardice in the performance of his duty;
without good and sufficient cause fails to carry out any lawful order, whether written or verbal;
is insubordinate towards any member whose orders it is his duty to obey;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: neglects or without good and sufficient cause fails to do, promptly and diligently, anything it is his duty to do;

paragraph.name: b

subsection.content: knowingly makes any false, misleading, or inaccurate statement in connexion with his duty either verbally or in writing;
with intent to deceive destroys any official record, document or book or alters or erases any entry therein;

subsection.leadIn: without proper authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: divulges any matter which it is his duty to keep secret;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: directly or indirectly communicates to the press or to any other person any matter which may have come to his knowledge in the course of his official duties;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: publishes any matter or makes any public pronouncement relating to the Fire Services Department; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: solicits or receives any unauthorized fee, gratuity or other consideration in connexion with his duties as a member;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to account for, or to make a prompt and true return of, any money or property for which he is responsible, either in connexion with his duties as a member or with any fund connected with the Fire Services Department or the Fire Services Department staff; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: improperly uses his position as a member;

subsection.leadIn: without proper authority or reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: absents himself from duty or from any place of parade;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arrives late for any duty or parade;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: wilfully or negligently damages or loses any articles of clothing or equipment, or any implement, accoutrement or appointment whatever, with which he has been provided or entrusted, or fails to take proper care thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: neglects to report any damage to, or loss of, any article of clothing or equipment, or any implement, accoutrement or appointment whatever, with which he has been provided or entrusted; (Amended L.N. 63 of 1992)

subsection.content: when on duty, or called upon for duty, is unfit for duty by reason of intoxicating drink or of drugs taken otherwise than under medical direction; (Amended 29 of 1975 s. 21)

when on or off duty acts in a disorderly manner, or in any manner prejudicial to discipline, or likely to bring discredit upon the Fire Services Department or the public service; (Amended 42 of 1961 s. 2)
is guilty of anything, whether by reason of contravention of government regulations or otherwise, which amounts to misconduct in a public office. (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

heading.inline: Rules for Investigation into Offences against Discipline by Subordinate Officers and Members of Other Ranks

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation of this Part
section.def: barrister (大律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159);
hearing (聆訊) means a hearing conducted in respect of an offence against discipline;
solicitor (律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159).

section.name: s2
section.heading: Charge sheet
section.content: Every charge must be entered on a charge sheet.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Investigation of charge
section.content: Every charge is to be investigated by the Director by way of a hearing under this Part without delay.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Appointment of prosecutor
section.content: The Director must appoint a prosecutor for the purposes of the proceedings against an accused under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: An accused may be represented at a hearing by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (subject to the Director’s approval) a barrister or solicitor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person of the accused’s choice who is approved by the Director for the purpose,

subsection.continued: and the person specified in paragraph (a) or (b) may conduct the defence on the accused’s behalf.

subsection.content: If the Director gives approval under subrule (1)(a), the accused may be represented at the hearing by a barrister or solicitor of the accused’s choice.
Despite subrule (1), the accused must attend the hearing in person.
If the accused is represented at the hearing by a barrister or solicitor, the Director and the prosecutor may separately be assisted by a barrister or solicitor at the hearing.
The Director must read and explain to the accused any charge against the accused.

subsection.leadIn: The prosecutor or any barrister or solicitor assisting the prosecutor may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: call any witness;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cross-examine any witness giving evidence for the accused; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make any statement in support of the charge.

subsection.leadIn: The accused or the defence representative may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cross-examine any witness giving evidence against the accused;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: call any witness; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make any statement to defend the accused.

subsection.content: Evidence must not be taken on oath or affirmation.
No documentary evidence may be used against the accused unless a copy of the documentary evidence, or access to the documentary evidence or a copy, has been given to the accused before the hearing.
The prosecutor may amend a charge or add a new charge at any time before the Director communicates a finding to the accused.
The Director must read and explain any amended or new charge to the accused.
The accused is entitled to a reasonable adjournment to prepare a further defence.

subsection.leadIn: The prosecutor and the accused—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may recall any witness who has given evidence for the purpose of further examination, cross-examination or re-examination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may call any further witness.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Proceedings in accused’s absence
section.content: Where an accused is required to appear in person in any proceedings under this Part and repeatedly fails to appear, the Director may proceed in the accused’s absence if satisfied that the accused has no reasonable excuse for the failures.

subsection.content: The Director must make, or cause to be made, a written record of the proceedings of a hearing.
The Director may make, or cause to be made, an audio recording or audio and visual recording of the proceedings, or any part of the proceedings, of a hearing.

subsection.leadIn: At the conclusion of a hearing, the Director must—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: if in the Director’s opinion the evidence shows that an offence against discipline has been committed, either—

subparagraph.content: award a punishment within the Director’s powers; or
refer the case to the Chief Executive.

subsection.content: Any punishment awarded must be entered in the conduct sheet of the accused so punished.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Reference of case to Chief Executive

subsection.leadIn: If the Director refers a case to the Chief Executive, the Director must forward to the Chief Executive—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the charge sheet;

paragraph.name: b

subparagraph.content: the Director’s reasons for considering the charge proved;
the Director’s recommendation with respect to punishment or otherwise; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the accused’s conduct sheet.

subsection.content: The Director must inform the accused by notice in writing that the accused may, within 14 days from the service of the notice, forward any further representations that the accused wishes to make to the Chief Executive in writing.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Procedure when case referred to Chief Executive
section.leadIn: On reference to the Chief Executive of a case and after consideration of any representations made by the accused, the Chief Executive must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if in the Chief Executive’s opinion the charge has not been proved, either—

subparagraph.content: dismiss the charge; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if in the Chief Executive’s opinion the charge is proved, or if, after any further or fresh investigation ordered under paragraph (a)(ii), the Chief Executive is of that opinion, award a punishment within the Chief Executive’s powers.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Procedure where Director has delegated powers

subsection.leadIn: If the Director has authorized under section 6(2) of this Ordinance any other person to exercise or perform the Director’s powers, functions or duties under rules 10, 11 and 12 of this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference in those rules to the Director is to be regarded as a reference to that other person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference in those rules to the Chief Executive is to be regarded as a reference to the Director.

subsection.content: A case referred to the Director by another person under rule 10(1)(b)(ii) of this Part as modified by subrule (1) may be referred to the Chief Executive by the Director in accordance with rule 11 of this Part.

heading.inline: Rules for Awarding Punishment where a Criminal Offence has been Committed by a Subordinate Officer or a Member of other Ranks

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: In the case of a subordinate officer, the Director shall as soon as practicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refer the case to the Chief Executive; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify the subordinate officer that he has done so and that the subordinate officer may make representations in writing to the Chief Executive in mitigation of punishment within 14 days of receiving such notice or within such further period as the Chief Executive may allow.

section.name: s2
section.leadIn: In referring a case under rule 1 the Director shall send to the Chief Executive—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the officer’s conduct sheet; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the recommendation of the Director with respect to punishment or otherwise.

section.name: s3
section.content: The Chief Executive may, after considering any representations made by the officer, award any one or more of the punishments which he may award under paragraph (1) of Part I of the Third Schedule in respect of a disciplinary offence by a subordinate officer.

section.name: s4
section.content: In the case of a member of other ranks, the Director shall notify the member that he may make representations in writing in mitigation of punishment within 14 days of receiving such notification and, after considering any such representations, may award any one or more of the punishments which he may award under Part II of the Third Schedule.

schedule.name: sch4
schedule.heading: Rights of Appeal and Related Provisions

section.name: s1
section.leadIn: A subordinate officer or member of other ranks (including one who has been dismissed) may appeal, in accordance with the following rules, against—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a finding by the Director or other member that he is guilty of a disciplinary offence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any punishment awarded by the Director or other member, other than under rule 4;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any order or requirement for payment in respect of loss or damage made by the Director under section 14C. (Added 4 of 1986 s. 6)

section.name: s2
section.content: A member of other ranks may also appeal, in accordance with the following rules, against a punishment awarded to him by the Director under Part II of the Second Schedule.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the Chief Executive, in respect of a finding made or punishment awarded by the Director; and (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the Director, in all other cases.

section.name: s4
section.leadIn: Upon an appeal, the Chief Executive or the Director, as the case may be, may— (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: confirm or reverse the finding;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: confirm the punishment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subject to rule 9, substitute any other punishment which could have been awarded in the first instance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: remit the punishment in full or in part without substituting any other punishment;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if he dismisses an appeal against a finding and no punishment has been awarded, treat the appeal as if it were a case referred to him for punishment and award any punishment or take any other action which he is authorized to take.

section.name: s5
section.content: Upon a review under section 14B(3) the Director may exercise any of the powers in rule 4(a), (b), (c) or (d).

section.name: s6
section.content: An appeal shall be made in writing within 14 days from the day on which the subordinate officer or member of other ranks is informed that he has been found guilty of an offence or from any later day on which punishment is awarded for that offence.

section.name: s7
section.leadIn: For the purpose of any appeal against a finding, the Chief Executive or the Director, as the case may be, may— (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: hear any additional evidence which he may consider relevant,

section.continued: and the Director may exercise the like powers where he reviews a finding under section 14B(3).

section.name: s8
section.content: In the event of an appeal, any punishment (other than a reprimand or severe reprimand) awarded to a subordinate officer or a member of other ranks shall be suspended until the appeal is disposed of or abandoned.

section.name: s9
section.content: Neither the Director nor the Chief Executive shall award a greater punishment under rules 4 and 5 without first allowing the subordinate officer or member of other ranks a reasonable opportunity to be heard or to make representations in writing as to why the punishment should not be increased. (Amended 76 of 1999 s. 3)
